awd_abstract_narration:
This project enables biologists to reach “through the looking glass” to construct and manipulate the mirror-image counterparts of the genetic molecules of life — the nucleic acids DNA and RNA. Complex molecules and their mirror-images are structurally distinct, like left and right hands, a property known as chirality. The biomolecules found in all known life on Earth are homochiral, consisting exclusively of left-handed proteins and right-handed nucleic acids. The mirror-images of these biomolecules, such as left-handed nucleic acids, are neither made nor recognized by the machinery of the cell. This property can be exploited to provide synthetic materials that are resistant to biological disruption and can be engineered to interact with their biological counterparts across the mirror for use in biotechnology and medicine. In this project, tools are being developed to synthesize unnatural left-handed nucleic acids, using recently developed right-handed nucleic acid enzymes. These “cross-chiral” enzymes also are being used to study why life as we know it is homochiral, and whether life that functions on both sides of the mirror is possible. The aim is to expand the reach of synthetic biology across the mirror, providing robust methods to generate mirror-image biomolecules, which will be made widely available to other researchers. This project is also training a diverse set of undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral scientists to use cross-chiral biology in their own research and will cultivate the next generation of scientists through a hands-on laboratory experience for high school students in chiral biology, encouraging their exploration of STEM fields.

The research builds on a toolkit of cross-chiral RNA enzymes, or “ribozymes”, that catalyze the synthesis of RNA polymers of the opposite handedness. New techniques for the directed evolution of polymerase ribozymes are being used to provide generalized methods for the synthesis of L-RNAs from simple and readily available starting materials and to amplify those L-RNAs using a cross-chiral form of the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). This toolkit will enable the construction of adaptive genetic systems that function in a fundamentally different way than known biology, addressing the meta-biological rules for how macromolecules of opposite handedness can interact to support enzymatic catalysis, genetics, and evolution. In parallel, the cross-chiral toolkit enables the scalable preparation of complex L-RNAs having a user-defined sequence, as exemplified by the synthesis of functional mirror-images of the RNA machinery of the cell. Molecular and synthetic biology have benefited from the progressive development of tools to manipulate the microscopic world, and the tools developed here aim to demonstrate that, likewise, there is plenty of room across the mirror.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Most complex molecules are chiral, with mirror-image left- and right-handed forms. Life on Earth is homochiral, using chiral molecules of only one handedness. Nucleic acids like DNA that operate as genetic molecules in our cells to store and transmit heritable information are always right-handed, whether in humans, plants, or microbes. Left-handed nucleic acids are not found in biology nor can cells recognize them. The molecular world on the other “side of the mirror” from nature can only be accessed in the laboratory, but only with great difficulty since the tools we need to engineer nucleic acids come from life and only interact with the right-handed forms.

The Cross-Chiral Genetic Systems project aims to study left-handed nucleic acids through collaborative research between laboratories at the Salk Institute in La Jolla, CA and Texas A&M University in College Station, TX. The project uses ribonucleic acid, or RNA, which is a cousin of DNA that plays critical roles in our cells and, increasingly, in biotechnology and medicine. The project also uses a “cross-chiral” RNA enzyme, built out of natural RNA, to assemble artificial left-handed “L-RNA” molecules from smaller L-RNA pieces that can be made chemically. This enzyme was the first such molecule to act across the mirror, and the current project sought both to improve the cross-chiral enzyme and to explore its use as a way to propagate left-handed genetic molecules.

The team improved the cross-chiral RNA enzyme using directed evolution, which harnesses Darwinian evolution to optimize enzymes for scientific and technological uses. New evolution methods for cross-chiral RNA enzymes were developed that significantly improve L-RNA assembly. Each molecule of the improved enzyme can produce up to 50 L-RNA molecules in an hour, the fastest rate of cross-chiral RNA synthesis ever achieved.

The project also made the chemistry of assembling L-RNA more efficient and accessible to non-specialist laboratories. The team developed three different techniques for activating small pieces of L-RNA for assembly into larger molecules. This culminated in a general method that can easily be performed by any biochemist to assemble L-RNA, which together with the improved cross-chiral RNA enzyme, provides laboratories with an “off-the-shelf” solution to study large L-RNA molecules.

The project also aimed to explore how left-handed nucleic acids can be replicated across the mirror. Nucleic acid replication is the fundamental reaction of life that passes genes from parent to progeny. It is also an important tool for biotechnology that drives the polymerase chain reaction or “PCR”. Early in the project, the cross-chiral RNA enzyme was used to replicate L-RNA by “riboPCR”, an analog of PCR that works across the mirror, allowing L-RNA molecules to be assembled and amplified more easily.

A more fundamental breakthrough in nucleic acid replication across the mirror was made during the last year of the project, after improving the cross-chiral enzyme. The activity of an RNA enzyme is flipped when made of mirror-image L-RNA, like left and right are flipped in a mirror. When the cross-chiral enzyme is used to make the mirror-image version of itself as L-RNA, the L-RNA enzyme in turn can assemble natural RNA. A mixture of both the right- and left-handed cross-chiral enzymes can thus make each other, collectively replicating across the mirror. The pair of molecules grow exponentially just as cells do, representing a new type of nucleic acid replication never seen in nature.

More broadly, the Cross-Chiral Genetic Systems project has explored a new way in which the laws of biological organization are not uniquely tied to the natural world but can be engineered. Using the tools of synthetic chemistry and biology, we can access alternative biologies across the mirror and can demonstrate that essential functions of life like replication need not operate exclusively on one side of the mirror. The project has made tools to explore this mirror world available to other scientists and has trained three new scientists in this area of research across the two institutions. Further work in mirror biology can follow, for scientific research or technological application, or as explained in one of the five scientific articles resulting from this project: “Life as we know it is homochiral, but life as it might be realized in the laboratory need not be considered so narrowly.”
